<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: outputFile.printf("The sum of the %d numbers is %.2f\n and the average is %.2f", numberOfNumbers, sum, average);
<<<explanation>>>: To print the sum and average to the output file, you can use the printf method of the PrintWriter class. This method allows you to format the output using placeholders (%d for integer, %.2f for floating point numbers). You can pass the variables numberOfNumbers, sum, and average as arguments to the printf method to print them in the desired format.

<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: outputFile.printf("The sum of the %d numbers is %.2f\n and the average is %.2f", numberOfNumbers, sum, average);
<<<explanation>>>: To print the sum and average to the output file, you can use the printf method of the PrintWriter class. This method allows you to format the output using placeholders (%d for integer, %.2f for floating-point numbers).

<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: outputFile.printf("The sum of the %d numbers is %.2f\n", numberOfNumbers, sum);
outputFile.printf("The average is %.2f\n", average);
<<<explanation>>>: To output the sum and average to the output file, you can use the `printf` method of the `PrintWriter` class. This method allows you to format the output using placeholders (%d for integers and %.2f for floating-point numbers with 2 decimal places). Simply replace the `System.out.println` statements with `outputFile.printf` statements to write the desired output to the file.

<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: outputFile.printf("The sum of the %d numbers is %.2f%n", numberOfNumbers, sum);
outputFile.printf("The average is %.2f%n", average);
<<<explanation>>>: To print the number of numbers, sum, and average to the output file, you can use the `printf` method of `PrintWriter`. This method allows you to format the output using placeholders and arguments. In this case, you can use `%d` for the number of numbers, `%.2f` for the sum and average with 2 decimal places, and `%n` for the line break.
